name: Pointcloud
tagline: A PostgreSQL extension for storing point cloud (LIDAR) data.
body:
### Welcome to pgPointCloud simple home site

#### Introduction ####
 `@TODO : put a nice image in background`

* Lidar point cloud are becoming more and more available. Devices are easy to get, not too expensive, and provide very accurate 3D points.
* Yet storing and using those Billions of points is a challenge.
*  **pgPointCLoud** is an open source PostgreSQL extension for storing point cloud (LIDAR) data and use it with PostGIS.
* It is very easy to use, robust and efficient.
* By storing Lidar point in a PostgreSQL database, pgPointCloud eases many problems and allows a good integration with other geo-spatial data (vector,raster) into one common framework : PostGIS.

#### What can be done with pgPointCloud? ####

 * pgPointCloud offers a way to efficiently store points in a postgres database.
 * In fact, pgpPointCloud stores _groups_ of points (pcPoints) called pcPatch
 * storing groups of point allows efficient compression of data.
 * This patch have a bounding box which can be used by PostGIS spatial features to greatly accelerate queries.
 * pgPointCloud allow then to efficiently _query_ very big point cloud.
 * Querying can be done using spatial criteria (which points are in this area), as well as point attributes criteria (which points have a value of this attribute between .. and ... ?)

 * The point cloud being in a server, they can be used for processing or visualization, or streamed.

#### Why use pgPointCloud to store Lidar points into postgreSQL and not in point cloud files?####

 * The traditional way of storing point cloud is using several files containing each a part of the point cloud
 * This as some severe limitations (that could be solved, that would amount to recreate a small postgres/postGis)
  * Not efficient data query (to get a few points, you need to read the whole file)
  * no concurrency (only one user can modify points at a time/read points at a time)
  * files tends to get duplicated a lot (each worker has it's own private version)
  * no security of data ( file could be corrupted by a processing, hard to manage who access what)
  * Hard to use several different point cloud at the same time
  * Hard to use point cloud with other spatial data (vector, raster, images)
 * pgPointCloud solves all of this problem, at a very low cost: you have to use a DBMS.

#### Does pgPointCloud scale? ####
 * pgPointCloud is a young project, yet it has been proven to work fast (1ms query time) with a 5 billions points cloud.
 * Currently pgPointCloud is fast for
  - [x] Load data into DB
  - [x] automatically compress data
  - [x] Query patches based on spatial or other attributes
 * It is slow for
  - [ ] Data output (100k pts/sec)
  - [ ] In base conversion (no functions)

#### Resources ####
 * [pgPointCloud repository](https://github.com/pramsey/pointcloud#pointcloud) with very thorough step by step demo
 * [pgPointCloud mailing list](http://lists.osgeo.org/cgi-bin/mailman/listinfo/pgpointcloud)
 * pgPointCloud documentation
  * [General presentationof pgPointCloud by its creator @pramsey](http://boundlessgeo.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/10/pgpointcloud-foss4-2013.pdf) 
  * [A testimony of successful uses of pgPointCloud in a vector/raster/Lidar framework ](http://www.coordinatesolutions.com/download/Jan2013OGI%20Presentation.pdf)
  * [An Advanced presentation of various usages of a Point Cloud server, starting from basic to very complex examples](https://github.com/Remi-C/Postgres_Day_2014_10_RemiC/raw/master/presentation/A%20PostgreSQL%20Server%20for%20Point%20Cloud%20Storage%20and%20Processing.pdf)
  * [A scientific paper comparing a pgPointCloud solution and a MonetDB solution](http://foss4g-e.org/sites/default/files/11-Martinez-Rubi_0.pdf)
